sentences: Ükski inimene ei saa mind selles asjas aidata.
Tal pole ühtegi sugulast ega sõpra.
Ta suudab siin rohkem ära teha kui ükski teine mees.
context: The Estonian word 'ükski' is an indefinite pronoun used in negative sentences to indicate that the negation applies to the entire class of persons, things or phenomena mentioned with the main noun. It functions similarly to English words like 'no one', 'not any', or 'nobody'. When used independently, it means 'no one' or 'nobody'. In comparative clauses in affirmative sentences, it indicates that the comparison basis includes all individual cases within the group being compared.
